Posts.Content: Mar 30, 2008 09:07AM Held wrote: muttnut, I too did things that were on the "no-no" list (before I found it!).  Binney calmed me down and peeled me off the roof!  Do you know how may lymph nodes they took?  What about instructions from the hospital?  At one of my follow-ups with the onco, she told me that I didn't have that many removed, so some of my restrictions were lifted.  And as far as lifting, I now lift weights 2-3 times a week.  Nothing major, but you get the idea.  Are you feeling more pain than before you saved your dog?
Posts.Title: had surgery Monday - lifting??? muttnut muttnut

Posts.Content: Held wrote: I had my bilat in 10/07 with tissue expanders.  Starting with the last 2 fills on my right side (end of January), my skin on the top of my breast, towards the center started to itch like crazy.  My exchange was the end of July, and the itching decreased slightly, but continues.  Nothing relieves the itch for long.  I just want to dig my fingernails into my chest!  The itch reminds me of the itch on my belly when I was pregnant with my second.  At least I could see the light at the end of the tunnel with that one!  If this is itching related to my skin stretching, shouldn't it have stopped by now? Any words of wisdom? A good friend will come and bail you out of jail....but a true friend will be sitting next to you saying.....Damn....that was fun! Dx 9/6/2007, DCIS, 6cm+, Grade 3, 0/3 nodes, ER+/PR- Log in to post a reply
Posts.Title: Will I ever stop itching? Held Moderators

Posts.Content: Sep 23, 2008 09:21PM Held wrote: I can feel when I scratch.  I itch at the top inner edge of my right breast. I don't itch  24/7 anymore, but when it is there, it is pretty intense.  I think I irritate my skin when I scratch, so I get some relief of that with some lotions  I use.  They seem to cool my skin for a bit.  I can't wait for it to stop!  I know I told my PS about it before - I came for a fill once covered in bio-oil!  My onco was a little concerned but when I told her it was in that one particular spot she seemed blow it off.  I have to stop thinking about it! It just makes me itch more!!!!!!!!!!!

Posts.Title: Nurses with Breast Cancer Jo_Ann_K PatRN10

Posts.Content: Apr 21, 2008 04:30AM Held wrote: I know you are scared.  This sucks.  I wish this was not happening to you.  Personally, the stats freaked me out so much, I finally stopped looking at them.  At one point in my life I did have harmless little cycts in my breasts (clearly not my current problem).  Try to take a deep breath, take someone with you to the doc as a second set of ears, and listen to what he/she has to say about what  the mammo/us results looked like and what it might mean, what they might expect to find from the biopsy.  They really will not know for sure without the results of the biopsy.   My heart goes out to you.  I pray this turns out to be nothing to worry about at all.  Let us know how you make out. Hugs

UGH!  HELP PLEASE!!!!!!
Posts.Title: Deep breathing to help LE? AlaskaDeb Binney4

Posts.Content: Aug 29, 2008 01:11AM Held wrote: I feel your pain as well. I am so sorry you are having such hard time. My mast was 10/07, 4 weeks later I was in the hospital having surgery to clean out the infected side.  4 weeks after that the doc had to take out the expander because the infection would not clear.  I waited 3 1/2 months to heal (it was my choice to wait this long) before letting him try another expander.  I think my doc wwould have done the lat flap if I had wanted to speed up the process, but I really didn't want the lat flap. I can also remember feeling like a freak with one side standing at attention and the other all wrinkled up.  I wore my boob-in-a-box for special occasions, but most of the time I didn't wear anything, because no one noticed (I wear scrubs to work, and baggy shirt most of the time).  When all this started (my mammo was 1 year ago today), I could not imagine having to wait a whole year to get put back together, I didn't think I would survive that long, and the doc was going to try to do it in 6-9. But after all the crap with the infection, I just wanted to make sure I was strong and healthy before we tried to move forward.  My exchange was 7/25, and my doc would be doing my nips any day now, but again I chose to make sure I was recovered enough to tolerate another 1-2 hour surgery (my exchange last about 2 1/2), so I am putting it off a month.  I can't wait to get all this done and over with.  I was really, reallly, really, really was hoping to be done by the anniversary of my mast., but I will be close. I will just have my tats left. I am sure you are disappointed that your reconstuction is being delayed.  It really sucks, but it sounds like your doc has your best interest at heart by wanting you to heal complely before he tries again. I have to be honest, I am personally concerned that you are still running a fever.  Does your doc know?  How many different antibiotic have you been on?
Posts.Title: Removal of Tissue Expander due to Infection csifinski Kinclan

Posts.Content: Held wrote: When I first me with my MD following my biopsy (which showed high grade DCIS), I THINK she said I would not need radiation after the surgery unless the cancer had spread to the chest wall.   I am getting confused about two things: 1) I have read in many places that radiation after the mastectomy for DCIS in the norm.   2) I was told I would no longer need an annual mammogram after the mastectomy, but I have read in several places you still need them - what the heck would they be looking AT?  A good friend will come and bail you out of jail....but a true friend will be sitting next to you saying.....Damn....that was fun! Posts.Content: Sep 1, 2008 08:47AM Held wrote: I had Aetna at the time of my bilat.  My dx was dcis in the left breast, MRI of the right showed it to have fibroids, but nothing else.  My genetic testing was covered (no direct ca link, but many aunts, uncles, and 2 grandparents dx with other types of ca) 100%.  I consulted 4 docs before I made my decision to have the bilat.  The onco said the bilat would be a "drastic" measure, but another doc felt it was the only choice because they didn't think I would be able to tolerate the tamox.  Everything but my co-pays were covered.  When I spoke to the rep from the insurane company who deals with BC patients, she told me I had "a good insurance plan" - it better be, I was paying close to $1000.00/month for it.  I now have Keystone, and again they have covered all.  I don't get how any insurance company would deny paying for a bilat. and recon.  They would rather pay for full treatment if it happens in the other breast later?
Posts.Title: Insurance and the healthy breast Journey BethNY

Posts.Content: Sep 21, 2008 10:54AM Held wrote: I too am a nurse, but I really don't like to admit it on the boards. I don't work in onco, and my nerves have me such a mess I can't comprehend what the docs are saying to ME sometimes.  I have a degree in nursing so everyone thinks I should have all the answers, but honestly I think having a little bit of knowledge makes me feel like (and look like) an idiot!  Add that to the fact that even my docs sometimes can agree on the dx or treatment, and I feel like I am underwater sometimes.  Please tell me someone else out there has had this problem!
Posts.Title: Nurses with Breast Cancer Jo_Ann_K PatRN10
